meanings.definition: A graph that is a subset of another graph.
meanings.sent1: In the computer science class, we learned about a subgraph that is a smaller part of a bigger graph.
meanings.sent2: The subgraph only includes some of the points and lines from the main graph.
meanings.sent3: I heard a joke about a subgraph that tried to be the center of attention but ended up being just a small part of the whole picture.
meanings.sent4: Her group of friends was like a subgraph in the school, connected to different circles but not part of the main clique.
meanings.sent5: The subgraph was like a tiny island in the vast ocean of the main graph, isolated yet connected in its own way.

meanings.definition: A graph that contains a subset of the vertices and edges of another graph.
meanings.sent1: The subgraph had only a few dots and lines compared to the original graph.
meanings.sent2: When studying networks, it's important to understand how a subgraph can represent a smaller section of the whole system.
meanings.sent3: At the math competition, the subgraph made a funny appearance, trying to fit in with the larger graphs but standing out as a unique piece.
meanings.sent4: The subgraph was like a hidden treasure map within the larger graph, revealing secrets in its limited space.
meanings.sent5: As I explored the graph, the subgraph stood out like a small puzzle piece waiting to be connected to the rest of the picture.
